g.text: We consider a population of size
, where each individual can be either a Cooperator (
when participating in a N-player Collective-Risk dilemma (
. In this game, each participant starts
(viewed as the asset value at stake) that may be used to contribute to the mitigation
of the effects of climate change. A cooperator incurs a cost corresponding to a fraction
, in order to help prevent a collective failure. On the other hand, a defector refuses to have any cost, hoping to
free ride on the contributions of others. We require a minimum number of 0
before collective action is realized; if a group of size
1) stands as the risk of collective failure. Otherwise,
everyone will keep whatever she has. This
formulation has been shown to capture some of the key features
, while highlighting the importance of risk. In addition, it allows one to
test model parameters in a systematic way that is not possible in human experiments. Moreover, the adoption of
non-linear returns mimics situations common to many human and non-human endeavors
mum joint effort is required to achieve a collective goal. Thus, the applicability of this framework extends well
beyond environmental governance, given the ubiquity of such type of social dilemmas in nature and societies.
, we include both reward and punishment mechanisms in this model. A fixed group
0 stands for a per-capita incentive) is assumed to be available, of which a fraction
applied to a reward policy and the remaining 1-
to a punishment policy. We assume the effective impact of both
policies to be equivalent, meaning that each unit spent will directly increase/decrease the payoff of a cooperator/
defector by the same amount. For details on policies with different efficiencies, see Methods.
Instead of considering a collection of rational agents engaging in one-shot Public Goods Games
adopt an evolutionary description of the behavioral dynamics
, in which individuals tend to copy those appearing
to be more successful. Success (or fitness) of individuals is here associated with their average payoff. All individu-
als are equally likely to interact with each other, causing all cooperators and defectors to be equivalent, on average,
and only distinguishable by the strategy they adopt. Therefore, and considering that only two strategies are avail-
able, the number of cooperators is sufficient to describe any configuration of the population. The number of indi-
) evolves in time according to a stochastic birthâ€“death process
which describes the time evolution of the social learning dynamics (with exploration): At each time-step each
) is given the opportunity to change strategy; with probability
(a process similar to mutations in a biological context that precludes the existence of absorb-
may adopt the strategy of a randomly selected individual (
), with a probability that increases with the fitness difference (
(see Methods) an extremely useful tool to rank the most visited states given the ensuing evolutionary dynamics
of the population. Indeed, the stationary distribution provides the prevalence of each of the populationâ€™s possible
configuration, in terms of the number of
. Combined with the probability of success charac-
terizing each configuration, the stationary distribution can be used to compute the overall success probability of
a given population â€“ the average group achievement,
. This value represents the average fraction of groups that
we compare the average group achievement
(as a function of risk) in four scenarios: (
., no reward or punishment, in black); and three scenarios where a budget is
a combination of rewards and sanctions (see below). Our results
are shown for the two most paradigmatic regimes: low (Fig.Â
improves whenever a policy is applied. Less obvious is the difference between the various policies.
Applying only rewards (blue curves in Fig.Â
) is more effective than only punishment (red curve) for low values of
risk. The opposite happens when risk is high. On scenarios with a low relative threshold (Fig.Â
the key role, with sanctions only marginally outperforming them for very high values of risk. For high coordina-
) reward and punishment portray comparable efficiency in the promotion of cooperation,
Justifying these differences is difficult from the analysis of
alone. To better understand the behavior dynam-
ics under Reward and Punishment, we show in Fig.Â

butions (lower panels) for each case and different budget values. Each gradient of selection represents, for each

Naturally, both mechanisms are inoperative whenever the per-capita incentives are inexistent (
ing a natural reference scenario in which to study the impact of Reward and Punishment on the
case, above a certain value of risk (
), decision-making is characterized by two internal equilibria (
finite population states with opposite gradient sign, representing the analogue of fixed points in a dynamical
system characterizing evolution in infinite populations). Above a certain fraction of cooperators the population
overcomes the coordination barrier and naturally self-organizes towards a stable co-existence of cooperators
and defectors. Otherwise, the population is condemned to evolve towards a monomorphic population of defec-
tors, leading to the tragedy of the commons
. As the budget for incentives increases, using either Reward or
Punishment leads to very different outcomes, as depicted in Fig.Â
Contrary to the case of linear Public Goods Games
ics already exist in the absence of any reward/punishment incentive. Reward is particularly effective when
